excerpt: Self-guided Titanic museum offering 9 interactive galleries that re-tell the iconic story.
detail_description: Titanic Belfast is an extraordinary museum that stands proudly on the grounds of the historic Harland and Wolff shipyard, where the Titanic was born. This self-guided experience features nine interactive galleries that take visitors on a captivating journey through Belfast's rich maritime history. From its origins as an 18th-century trading hub to becoming a powerhouse in industries like linen and shipbuilding, the museum intricately weaves together stories of innovation and tragedy.
name: Titanic Belfast
address: 1 Olympic Wy, Belfast, BT3 9EP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Classical Renaissance-style setting for displays on Irish art, natural history & industry.
detail_description: Nestled within the picturesque Botanic Gardens of Belfast, the Ulster Museum stands as Northern Ireland's largest museum, a treasure trove for art and history aficionados. Established in 1821, this classical Renaissance-style institution has evolved over the years to showcase an impressive array of exhibits that span from ancient artifacts to contemporary art. Visitors can marvel at everything from dinosaur skeletons and Egyptian mummies—like the remarkable Takabuti—to exquisite decorative arts including ceramics and textiles.
name: Ulster Museum
address: Belfast, BT9 5AB, United Kingdom

excerpt: Jail that closed in 1996 and now hosts public tours, live music and paranormal investigation events.
detail_description: Crumlin Road Gaol Visitor Attraction and Conference Centre is a captivating destination that invites visitors to delve into its rich history and intriguing past. Originally opened in 1846, this Victorian-era prison operated for 150 years before closing in 1996. Today, it offers self-guided tours enhanced by audio guides and holograms, allowing guests to wander through its eerie tunnels, compact cells, and even a haunting graveyard.
name: Crumlin Road Gaol Visitor Attraction and Conference Centre
address: 53-55 Crumlin Rd, Belfast, BT14 6ST, United Kingdom

excerpt: In addition to city offices, this ornate 1906 building has a cafe, public art & a Titanic garden.
detail_description: Belfast City Hall, an architectural gem completed in 1906, stands proudly at the heart of Belfast, symbolizing the city's Victorian-era prosperity. This stunning building features a grand Renaissance stone façade adorned with intricate designs and boasts an interior staircase crafted from exotic Italian marble, exuding a regal ambiance. Visitors are often captivated by its beauty, especially when illuminated at night or festively decorated during Christmas.
name: Belfast City Hall
address: Donegall Square N, Belfast, BT1 5GS, United Kingdom

excerpt: Castle within country park, with adventure playground, visitor centre, antiques shop and restaurant.
detail_description: Belfast Castle, located within Cave Hill Country Park, offers a fairytale-like setting with its impressive Scottish Baronial style architecture and conical roof towers. While the interior is reserved for events, visitors can still enjoy the adventure playground, antiques shop, restaurant, and visitor center. The castle's courtyard features a refreshing fountain and beautiful gardens that provide tranquility and stunning views of the city. Set on the slopes of Cave Hill Country Park, it offers breathtaking panoramic views of Belfast.
name: Belfast Castle
address: Antrim Rd, Belfast, BT15 5GR, United Kingdom

excerpt: Elaborate public garden dating to 1828, featuring tropical species & an elegant domed conservatory.
detail_description: Botanic Gardens, established in 1828, is a picturesque public garden in Belfast. The gardens boast a diverse collection of tropical plant species and an impressive domed conservatory. It spans 28 acres and offers a blend of horticultural wonders and open spaces for leisurely strolls. Throughout the year, the gardens host various events including festivals and concerts. Additionally, visitors can relax at the on-site café which is also ideal for studying or simply enjoying a change of scenery.
name: Botanic Gardens
address: College Park Ave, Botanic Ave, Belfast BT7 1LP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Zoo with a walk-through rainforest house that is active in wildlife conservation and breeding.
detail_description: Belfast Zoo, located in Northern Ireland, is a renowned visitor attraction with over 300,000 annual visitors. It houses more than 1,000 animals and 140 species, many of which are endangered. The zoo features popular attractions such as Asian elephants, giraffes, sea lions, penguins, apes, tapirs and tigers. Additionally, it offers a walk-through rainforest exhibit showcasing rare tropical plants and animals like sloths and fruit bats.
name: Belfast Zoo
address: Antrim Rd, Belfast, BT36 7PN, United Kingdom

excerpt: Colourful 19th-century market, active Friday to Sunday for fruit, flowers, fish, fashion & crafts.
detail_description: St George's Market is a vibrant and historic destination in Belfast, operating from Friday to Sunday. This colorful 19th-century market stands as the last remaining Victorian covered market in the city, showcasing an array of offerings including fresh fruits, flowers, fish, fashion items, and unique crafts. Food enthusiasts will find their paradise here on Saturdays during the City Food and Craft Market hours from 9 am to 3 pm.
name: St George's Market
address: 12 East Bridge St, Belfast, BT1 3NQ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Rugged hillside park with trails leading past several caves, an ancient fort & Belfast Castle.
detail_description: Cave Hill Country Park, located north of Belfast, is a rugged hillside park with trails leading past several caves and an ancient fort. The park offers waymarked routes starting from Belfast Castle, including an easy walk up to Cave Hill's famous Napoleons Nose. The park provides stunning panoramic views over Belfast and the lough. With popular hiking routes offering both city views and a rugged hiking experience in the surrounding hills, it's a staple for outdoor enthusiasts visiting Belfast.
name: Cave Hill Country Park
address: Antrim Rd, Belfast, BT5 5GR, United Kingdom

excerpt: Imposing, restored 1895 theatre and opera venue staging touring musicals, comedy, dance and drama.
detail_description: The Grand Opera House in Belfast is a stunning testament to the city's rich cultural heritage, having undergone an impressive restoration that celebrates its 1895 origins. Recently revitalized with a $12 million facelift just in time for its 125th anniversary, this iconic venue now boasts a beautifully restored auditorium adorned with intricate plasterwork and ornate boxes. Visitors can revel in the exquisite details crafted by renowned architect Frank Matcham, including striking ceilings and decorative features like elephant heads.
name: Grand Opera House
address: 2-4 Great Victoria St, Belfast, BT2 7HR, United Kingdom

excerpt: Belfast is Northern Ireland’s capital. It was the birthplace of the RMS Titanic, which famously struck an iceberg and sunk in 1912. This legacy is recalled in the renovated dockyards' Titanic Quarter, which includes the Titanic Belfast, an aluminium-clad museum reminiscent of a ship’s hull, as well as shipbuilder Harland & Wolff’s Drawing Offices and the Titanic Slipways, which now host open-air concerts.
detail_description: Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland, is renowned for its connection to the RMS Titanic and boasts a revitalized Titanic Quarter with attractions like the Titanic Belfast museum. The city has transformed into a vibrant destination with award-winning dining, trendy bars, and various tourist hotspots including the nearby Giants Causeway. Despite its troubled past during The Troubles, modern-day Belfast offers a serene atmosphere and is an ideal place for history enthusiasts and adventurous travelers looking for an authentic experience in Northern Ireland.
name: Belfast
address: UK

excerpt: Carved-mahogany booths, etched-glass, plus gas lamps feature in an 1820's pub, famed for its decor.
detail_description: The Crown Liquor Saloon, built in the 1880s, is a renowned pub in Belfast known for its stunning Victorian and Baroque interiors. The exterior boasts a multi-colored tiled facade with a distinctive crown motif at the entrance. Inside, visitors can admire the ornate red granite bar, intricate mosaic tiles, stained glass windows, and detailed woodwork. The pub's historic significance is further enhanced by its appearance in various films over the years.
name: The Crown Liquor Saloon
address: County Antrim, 46 Great Victoria St, Belfast BT2 7BA, United Kingdom

excerpt: Maritime museum aboard the storied ship built to carry 1st- & 2nd-class passengers to the Titanic.
detail_description: SS Nomadic is a must-see for maritime history enthusiasts and anyone intrigued by the shipping industry. This storied ship, the last of its kind from the White Star Line, has been meticulously restored to its former grandeur and is now part of a maritime museum in its original docks. As Titanic's original tender, SS Nomadic offers visitors a glimpse into the luxurious cruising life with similar design and opulent finishes.
name: SS Nomadic
address: Hamilton Dock, Queens Rd, Belfast, BT3 9DT, United Kingdom

excerpt: Hands-on exhibits & restored quarters & engine rooms on a navy C-class light cruiser built in 1914.
detail_description: When you think of Belfast, the Titanic often steals the spotlight, but don’t overlook HMS Caroline—a remarkable piece of naval history. This C-class light cruiser, built in 1914 and a lone survivor from the Battle of Jutland during World War I, has been beautifully restored into a floating museum. Visitors can explore its meticulously refurbished quarters and engine rooms while engaging with hands-on exhibits that bring maritime life to vivid reality.
name: HMS Caroline
address: Alexandra Dock, Queens Rd, Belfast BT3 9DT, United Kingdom

excerpt: 19th-century buildings, with recreators in period dress, plus festivals, courses and workshops.
detail_description: The Ulster Folk Museum, located just outside Belfast, offers a unique glimpse into Northern Ireland's past. Divided into two sections, the museum vividly brings the province's social history to life. The Folk Museum features a meticulously recreated early 20th-century town with costumed actors practicing traditional crafts. Visitors can explore various reconstructed buildings and witness regional skills such as lace making, wood turning, open-hearth cooking, and more.
name: Ulster Folk Museum
address: Cultra, Holywood, BT18 0EU, United Kingdom

excerpt: The upbeat Cathedral Quarter is a cultural and nightlife zone around Saint Anne’s Cathedral, a Romanesque church known for its organ recitals and needlelike steel spire. The MAC and the Black Box host theatre, comedy, and art shows, while food festivals and summer concerts fill Custom House Square. Hip Mediterranean bistros, craft coffee shops, and stylish modern pubs line narrow, cobbled lanes.
detail_description: Cathedral Quarter in Belfast is a vibrant cultural and nightlife hub centered around Saint Anne’s Cathedral. The area is known for its Romanesque church with organ recitals and a distinctive steel spire. The MAC and the Black Box are popular venues for theater, comedy, and art shows, while Custom House Square hosts food festivals and summer concerts. Charming cobbled lanes are lined with trendy Mediterranean bistros, craft coffee shops, and modern pubs.
name: Cathedral Quarter
address: Belfast, BT1 1RY, UK

excerpt: Interactive science centre with climbing & robot attractions, plus temporary exhibits & demos.
detail_description: W5 is an interactive science center located in the Odyssey Complex on Queens Quay. It offers over 250 hands-on stations across four exhibition zones, catering to children's curiosity and active engagement. The center features climbing attractions like Climbit and a multi-sensory Spacebase activity zone, as well as exhibits covering topics such as flight, electric circuits, natural forces, health, hygiene, and geology.
name: W5
address: The Odyssey, 2 Queens Quay, Belfast BT3 9QQ, United Kingdom

detail_description: The Giants Causeway Tour is a must-visit attraction in Northern Ireland, steeped in both myth and geology. This stunning rock formation features around 40,000 hexagonal basalt columns that tumble towards the sea, creating a dramatic sight against the Atlantic backdrop. While some believe these formations were created by volcanic activity, local legends attribute them to the giant Finn McCool. In addition to this iconic site, Northern Ireland offers other attractions such as the Titanic museum in Belfast and St.
name: Giants Causeway Tour
address: 29 Donegall Rd., Belfast, BT12 5JJ, United Kingdom

excerpt: University with Tudor-style main building, known for its humanities, science and medicine programs.
detail_description: Queen's University Belfast is a prestigious institution known for its strong programs in humanities, science, and medicine. The university's main building boasts a striking Tudor-style architecture that resembles Hogwarts, making it an iconic symbol of Belfast's academic heritage. Located near the city center, the campus is a hub of student life and research activities. The surrounding area offers vibrant experiences with locals enjoying good banter and fun-filled gatherings.
name: Queen's University Belfast
address: University Rd, Belfast, BT7 1NN, United Kingdom

excerpt: Expansive mid-18th century park with woodlands, meadows, formal gardens and a renowned rose garden.
detail_description: Sir Thomas and Lady Dixon Park is a vast park that dates back to the mid-18th century, boasting woodlands, meadows, formal gardens, and a famous rose garden. The park was established in honor of Lady Edith Dixon's philanthropy and generosity in the early 20th century.
name: Sir Thomas and Lady Dixon Park
address: Belfast, BT17 9LA, United Kingdom

excerpt: Clock tower built during the 1860s to memorialize Prince Albert, featuring a statue of the prince.
detail_description: The Albert Memorial Clock, built in the 1860s to honor Prince Albert, stands as one of Belfast's most iconic landmarks. This elegant structure combines French and Italian Gothic styles and features a statue of the prince. The clock is often compared to the Leaning Tower of Pisa, but it's the fountains beneath it that offer a striking photo opportunity from April to October. Designed by William J.
name: Albert Memorial Clock
address: 17 Queen's Square, Belfast, BT1 3FF, United Kingdom

excerpt: Section of wall erected to quell Northern Irish conflict, now a repository for art & messages.
detail_description: The Peace Wall in Belfast stands as a poignant reminder of the city's tumultuous past, originally erected to help quell the Northern Irish conflict. This remarkable structure has transformed into an open-air gallery adorned with vibrant murals that reflect the stories and sentiments of both nationalist and unionist communities. Visitors flock to this site not only to witness its artistic expressions but also to engage with locals who are often eager to share their rich history and cultural identity.
name: Peace Wall Belfast
address: 15 Cupar Way, Belfast, BT13 2RX, United Kingdom

excerpt: Panoramic city and mountain views spread from the nature trails through a wildlife-rich landscape.
detail_description: National Trust - Divis and the Black Mountain offers a 3-mile loop walk on Divis Mountain, providing moderate difficulty and stunning views of Belfast and Ulster. The pet-friendly area allows dogs on leashes to explore the unique ecosystem of bogs and ponds. With various hiking trails, visitors can enjoy panoramic city and mountain views while following the Countryside Code. Just a short 15-minute walk from Belfast, this spot is perfect for enjoying sunset panoramas of Northern Ireland.
name: National Trust - Divis and the Black Mountain
address: Divis Road Hannahstown, Belfast, BT17 0NG, United Kingdom

detail_description: Victoria Square is a prominent shopping center located in central Belfast, covering an eight-block area and dominating the city's skyline. The mall, spanning eight stories and 800,000 square feet, features a striking geodesic glass dome with a viewing gallery offering breathtaking panoramic views of the city. While the retail outlets and dining options on-site are typical of those found in malls across the UK, Victoria Square offers more than 75 stores and restaurants catering to various needs.
name: Victoria Square
address: 1 Victoria Square, Belfast, BT1 4QG, United Kingdom

detail_description: Embarking on a Black Taxi Tour Belfast is an essential way to delve into the city's rich history and culture. Knowledgeable drivers provide insightful commentary, offering a deep understanding of The Troubles and Belfast's turbulent past. The tour encompasses historic and religious events depicted on the city's walls, as well as modern murals celebrating sporting and cultural icons.
name: Black Taxi Tour Belfast
address: Unit 6, Curran House, 155 Northumberland St, Belfast BT13 2JF, United Kingdom

detail_description: Located in Belfast, Titanic Quarter is a thriving neighborhood that has undergone significant urban waterfront regeneration. It is home to the iconic Titanic Belfast museum, which offers an interactive experience detailing the history of Belfast and the story of the RMS Titanic. Visitors can also enjoy a drink at Hicksons Point next door, marked by a striking Dockers Rest mural on its exterior wall. This area is definitely worth a visit for those interested in maritime history and vibrant urban spaces.
name: Titanic Quarter
address: Belfast, BT4 1BP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Gardens & estate around Northern Ireland Assembly parliament with parks, trails & historic statues.
detail_description: Stormont Estate, located in Northern Ireland, is a picturesque and historic site surrounding the Northern Ireland Assembly parliament. The estate boasts beautiful gardens, parks, trails, and statues that make it an ideal destination for a romantic afternoon stroll or a leisurely outdoor adventure. It has been recognized with a Green Flag Award for its prestigious woodland park in east Belfast.
name: Stormont Estate
address: Stormont Ct, Belfast, BT4 3LP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Historic ground, now home to Ulster Rugby, opened in 1923 and hosting rugby matches ever since.
detail_description: Kingspan Stadium, a historic venue that has been the heart of rugby in Northern Ireland since its opening in 1923, is now the proud home of Ulster Rugby. After an extensive renovation from 2012 to 2014, this impressive stadium can host up to 18,000 enthusiastic fans who flock here for thrilling matches on Friday evenings and Saturday afternoons.
name: Kingspan Stadium
address: 134 Mount Merrion Ave, Belfast, BT6 0FT, United Kingdom

excerpt: Basaltic hill offering sweeping views of Belfast & Scotland, plus caves & an old ring fort.
detail_description: Cavehill, a stunning basaltic hill rising to 368 meters (1207 feet), is a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Belfast. This natural wonder not only offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city and the distant shores of Scotland but also features intriguing caves and an ancient ring fort known as McArts Fort. The accessible 4.
name: Cavehill
address: Newtownabbey, BT36 7WH, United Kingdom

excerpt: Huge yellow shipbuilding cranes, symbols of Belfast's industrial heritage, with 140m spans.
detail_description: The Samson & Goliath Cranes are two colossal yellow shipbuilding cranes located in the Titanic Quarter at the Harland & Wolff shipyard in Belfast. Built in 1969 and 1974, these iconic structures stand as symbols of the city's industrial legacy, named after the biblical figures. While access to the active industrial area is restricted, their towering presence makes them easily visible.
name: The Samson & Goliath Cranes
address: West Bank Drive, Belfast, BT3 9DF, United Kingdom

excerpt: Indoor stadium with 10,000 seats, hosting ice-hockey matches, ice shows, music and comedy events.
detail_description: The SSE Arena Belfast is a versatile indoor stadium with a seating capacity of 10,000. Located within the Titanic Quarter, it is a prime venue for various events including ice-hockey matches, ice shows, music concerts, and comedy events. It serves as the home stadium for the Belfast Giants ice hockey team and has hosted renowned music artists like Shania Twain, Bryan Adams, and Westlife.
name: SSE Arena Belfast
address: 2 Queens Quay, Belfast, BT3 9QQ, United Kingdom

detail_description: Stormont Park offers a rejuvenating woodland stroll with various attractions such as the Parliament Buildings, an impressive tree-lined avenue, and abundant wildlife like squirrels and birds. The Long Woodland Walk commences at the car park and is marked by orange arrows guiding visitors through woods and open parkland. The route encompasses some hilly terrain that may pose a challenge for individuals with lower fitness levels.
name: Stormont
address: Belfast, BT4 3SR, UK

detail_description: Colin Glen Forest Park is a top family attraction in Northern Ireland, featuring the popular Gruffalo Trail with sculptures from the beloved books and Ireland's only alpine coaster, the Black Bull Run. The park also offers a thrilling zip line experience. Located just a 20-minute drive from Belfast city, it's an ideal destination for families.
name: Colin Glen Forest Park
address: HXC8+HH, Belfast, BT17 0BU, United Kingdom

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Belfast, the Museum of Orange Heritage at Schomberg House offers a captivating journey through the rich history and traditions of the Orange Institution. This interpretative center delves into significant events starting from the Glorious Revolution to contemporary times, showcasing an impressive collection of artefacts that date back to 1689. Visitors can engage with interactive exhibits and cutting-edge audio-visual technologies that bring the story of Orangeism to life.
name: Museum of Orange Heritage - Free Admission
address: 368 Cregagh Rd, Castlereagh, Belfast BT6 9EY, United Kingdom

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Belfast, St Malachy's Church stands as a testament to the city's rich architectural heritage. As the third-oldest Catholic church in Belfast, it was consecrated in 1844 and showcases stunning Tudor Revival architecture. Originally designed to accommodate over 7,000 worshippers, financial limitations led to a more modest structure that still captivates visitors today.
name: St Malachy's Church
address: 24 Alfred St, Belfast, BT2 8EN, United Kingdom

excerpt: Ceramic fish sculpture with pictures & text on Belfast's history, including some by kids.
detail_description: The Big Fish, also known as the Salmon of Knowledge, is a famous ceramic sculpture located in Belfast. Created by artist John Kindness and installed in 1999, this 10-meter sculpture has become an iconic symbol of the city's regeneration along the River Lagan. The outer scales of the fish are adorned with intricate mosaics that depict Belfast's history and spirit, making it a popular spot for photography enthusiasts.
name: The Big Fish
address: Donegall Quay, Belfast, BT1 3NG, United Kingdom

excerpt: Classic pub down a cobbled alley with mirrored whiskey bar, old advertising signs and live music.
detail_description: The Duke of York is a classic pub located in a picturesque area of Belfast. It has a rich history, having been frequented by journalists and even employing Gerry Adams as a barman. The pub was rebuilt after being bombed during The Troubles and now features murals, pictures, and Northern Irish slogans as a tribute to the city. With its mirrored whiskey bar, old advertising signs, live music, craft beers, and whiskies, it offers a convivial spot for visitors.
name: Duke of York
address: 7-11 Commercial Ct, Belfast, BT1 2NB, United Kingdom

excerpt: Plaza & event space featuring sculptures of characters from "The Lion, the Witch & the Wardrobe."
detail_description: Nestled just off Newtownards Road in East Belfast, CS Lewis Square is a delightful plaza that brings the enchanting world of 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' to life. This charming space features seven stunning bronze sculptures depicting beloved characters like Aslan and Mr. Tumnus, making it a dream destination for photographers and fans alike.
name: CS Lewis Square
address: Visitor Centre, 402 Newtownards Rd, Belfast BT4 1HH, United Kingdom

excerpt: Exhibits on the Blitz and everyday life in the city during WWII, with memorials to those who died.
detail_description: The Northern Ireland War Memorial Museum, located in the vibrant Cathedral Quarter of Belfast, offers a compelling insight into the city's experiences during World War II. The museum showcases exhibits on the Belfast Blitz and everyday life during wartime, honoring those who made sacrifices. Visitors can explore the role of Northern Ireland in significant events such as the Luftwaffe bombing raids and the contributions of women and the Ulster Home Guard.
name: Northern Ireland War Memorial Museum
address: 21 Talbot St, Belfast, BT1 2LD, United Kingdom

detail_description: Clifton House is a beautifully restored 18th century mansion in the centre of Belfast. The building has been extensively renovated and now serves as a tourist attraction, with excellent facilities for hosting small meetings or events. It is an interesting place to visit whether you are interested in history or architecture, and the surrounding cemetery is still well looked after.
name: Clifton House
address: 2 N Queen St, Belfast, BT15 1ES, United Kingdom

excerpt: Simple, traditional venue filled with small tables and stools and serving beers, spirits and wines.
detail_description: Kelly's Cellars is a historic pub in Belfast, dating back to 1720. It holds a significant place in Irish history as it was a meeting place for the United Irishmen during the 1798 rebellion. The pub has retained its traditional charm with small tables and stools, worn bar, and bric-a-brac hanging from the vaulted ceiling. Visitors can enjoy traditional music by an open fire on select evenings or relax in the large covered street beer garden.
name: Kelly's Cellars
address: 30-32 Bank St, Belfast, BT1 1HL, United Kingdom

excerpt: Traditional looking pub with a modern vibe including a Jameson barrel sculpture in the beer garden.
detail_description: The Dirty Onion and Yardbird is a unique establishment in Belfast, housed in a historic timber-framed building dating back to 1680. It seamlessly combines traditional Irish pub aesthetics with modern elements, such as a Jameson barrel sculpture in the beer garden and the presence of Yardbird chicken restaurant. This fusion creates a hipster-friendly atmosphere while still retaining its soul as one of the finest places for traditional Irish live music.
name: The Dirty Onion and Yardbird
address: 3 Hill St, Belfast, BT1 2LA, United Kingdom

detail_description: Immerse yourself in the tumultuous history of Ireland by embarking on a Black Taxi Tour in West Belfast. These tours offer a unique perspective on The Troubles, a period of conflict that gripped Ireland for decades. Originally introduced as a safer mode of transportation during this turbulent time, black taxi cabs now serve as vessels for exploring the city's famous wall art and delving into its political and modern history.
name: Black Taxi Tours Belfast
address: 67 Squires Hill Rd, Belfast, BT14 8FS, United Kingdom

detail_description: In Belfast, a new attraction called the Glass of Thrones - The Iron Throne has emerged, featuring a walking trail that connects Belfast City Hall to the Game of Thrones Touring Exhibition and Titanic Studios. This 2.5-kilometer trail showcases six stained glass windows depicting iconic scenes from the TV show Game of Thrones. Whether you're a fan or not, this trail offers an enjoyable activity in Belfast, with each window representing significant moments from the first seven seasons of the series.
name: Glass of Thrones - The Iron Throne
address: Victoria Road, Belfast, BT3 9DU, United Kingdom

detail_description: Common Market in Belfast is a new addition to the city, offering a variety of street food and three bars all under one roof. The market provides an array of food options, making it an ideal spot for groups with diverse cravings. While exploring the area, visitors can also check out St Georges Market, which has stood the test of time since its construction in the late 19th century.
name: Common Market
address: 16-20 Dunbar St, Belfast, BT1 2LH, United Kingdom

detail_description: Titanic Belfast is a captivating tourist attraction in Belfast, Northern Ireland, dedicated to the legendary RMS Titanic. The museum offers an immersive experience that delves into the history of the ship, from its construction in the city's renowned shipyards to its tragic sinking. Visitors are taken on a curated tour through the conception, development, design, and building of the Titanic with engaging multimedia elements. The exhibition also sheds light on leadership failures and showcases Belfast as a charming city.
name: Titanic
address: Belfast, United Kingdom

detail_description: When exploring Belfast, immersing yourself in the city's rich history is a must, particularly the tumultuous era known as the Troubles. One of the most striking ways to connect with this past is through the vibrant political murals that adorn many walls throughout the city, representing both Catholic and Protestant perspectives. A self-guided tour by car allows you to take in these powerful artworks at your own pace—perfect for those traveling with pets who may not be welcome on organized tours.
name: Mural
address: 1 Church St, Belfast, BT1 1DL, United Kingdom

detail_description: If you're visiting Titanic Belfast, don't miss the Belfast Barge Museum. It's home to The Greatest Story Never Told, chronicling the lives of those who worked on the River Lagan, including the workers of Harland & Wolfe, builders of The Titanic. Entry is free but donations are appreciated to support this treasure trove of artifacts and visual displays from that era.
name: Belfast Barge Museum
address: 1 Lanyon Pl, 3LG, BT1 3LG, United Kingdom

detail_description: Embark on the Belfast Art Gallery Walking Tour and immerse yourself in the vibrant street art scene that defines this captivating city. As you wander through its streets, you'll encounter a stunning array of murals and graffiti that showcase the incredible artistic talent thriving here. These striking pieces not only beautify the urban landscape but also reflect the powerful ideas and stories of the local community.
name: Belfast Art Gallery Walking Tour
address: Donegall St, Belfast, BT1 2FF, United Kingdom

excerpt: Home of Northern Ireland's football team and notable club side, Linfield FC's league and cup games.
detail_description: The National Football Stadium at Windsor Park is a true gem for sports enthusiasts visiting Belfast. As the proud home of Northern Ireland's national football team and the renowned Linfield FC, this stadium pulsates with local passion and history. A 45-minute tour offers an exciting glimpse into the world of professional football, taking you through players' changing rooms, down the tunnel, and onto the pitch itself—perfect for fans of all ages.
name: Clearer Twist National Stadium at Windsor Park
address: Donegall Ave, Belfast, BT12 6LW, United Kingdom
